uptake of ARC and its impact on reducing vulnerability to disasters. It notes that there is scarce li
on disaster risk insurance mechanism in terms of impacts. In its current sample of 20 countries as of
November 2017, 4 are projected to experience food security crisis (IPC Level 3) but are not signatories
to the ARC which may signal that ARC is n
ot attractive to all food insecure countries and that there is
no overwhelming appetite for ARC among poorer countries. Additionally,
research on the importance of indicators and frameworks for monitoring the performance and impact

Examples of this support include, the Germany
Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) has provided 5.9 million USD for WFP
framers with climate risk insurance, through ARC Replica,
and the G7, InsuResilience Vision 2025, which has committed to ensuring 400
persons are covered against disaster shock by pre
arranged finance and insurance mechanism by 2025,
of this will be through ARC
. Of course, this does not mean tha
challenges or are not failing on specific sets of metrics.
holder and hazard coverage, the cost of premium an
d risk transfer parameters and the use of pay
which in most cases are up to the government. Here, ARC is flagged among the three regional Risk
pools, as the only one with contingency plan requirement that can support effective use of pay
esearch exploring climate risk pool and its impacts, flag lack of transparency around pay
premium or risk transfer parameters. Ultimately, climate risk pools are not full insurance; they offer
only limited coverage. Entities such as the UK Anti
tion Help desk is exploring how to mitigate
potential corruption with regard to climate risk insurance.
Widen the focus of relevant actors: Role of communities, cities and sub
There is an urgency and demand to meet the financial needs of
the climate change actions not only at
the national level but also at the subnational level, to achieve low
finance and investment is a necessary condition to achieve climate change mitigation and adaptation
The importance of exploring effective subnational climate finance.
cities to build more sustainable, climate
. It has transformative potential as a key enabler of inclusive urba
development through the building of resilient communities
Yet the significant potential of subnational climate
finance mechanisms remains unfulfilled. Policy frameworks, governance, and choices at higher levels
scale climate investment, a systematical understanding of the preconditions to mobilizing high
uments at the national and subnational levels is necessary.
Subnational climate finance needs and flows.
mechanisms reaching or utilizing subnational actors to develop climate positive investment in urban
. The fragility of interconnected national and subnational finances affects subnational finance
